content.description:
A varied line with a distinct face crux, Silverback follows a set of cracks interrupted by a 15' golden shield peppered with diagonal slits. It has the great honor of being the (almost) 100th route at the Jungle, the tallest at the Upper Jungle, and an mild obsession of mine since I first visited the place and spotted the shield.

Extract yourself from a prickly bush and follow a thin dihedral crack to a bolt. Leave the relative safety of the corner to mantle a shelf and find yourself face to face with the intimidating shield. Clip a second bolt and cast off through a series of powerful sidepulls and highsteps culminating in a committing throw. Take a quick breath, sink a couple of pieces and commit to a few more thin moves to gain a laser-cut crack and the first decent feet in a while.

The theme of the adventure changes to hand jams, fist jams and the occasional lieback or face move up the rapidly expanding crack.

The protection in the last 30' is adequate but not straightforward as the crack is formed on the right side by a pile of blocks that would make any sea stack off the coast of England pale in shame. Some cams need to go in deep to reach good pods. We cleaned the crack as well as we could but sanitizing it would require sending the whole pillar down. Tread lightly, keep your eyes peeled for feet on the solid left face and treat the holds on the pillar to your right as possible traitors.
content.protection:
Two bolts.

Medium nuts, single set of cams from micros (green C3) to #2. Double or even triple #3 and one or two #4.

Chain anchor at the top.

Long runners are useful for the few cams you'll bury deep in the upper section of the crack.
content.location:
Silverback climbs the left side of the Gorillas in the Crack Pillar, starting about 10' to the left in a prickly brush creeping up a small dihedral.

The route bisects a distinctive golden shield split by diagonal fractures.

content.description: A thin and varied crack up a short, steep face. Begin on the right side of the wall, follow a staggering crack to a two-bolt anchor. Good gear with a few nice rests, varied and interesting climbing.
content.protection: A single rack of cams and nuts.
content.location:
Directly right of

Grape Ape

and just left of the

Baby Gorilla Gully.

content.description: This is a stemming problem in a right-facing dihedral.  Feet are most often on opposite faces and the crack is used primarily for protection.
content.protection: Medium to wide cams to chains.
content.location: This climb, in the "Upper Jungle" is left of "Gorillas in the Crack" and right of "Great Ape Escape" in a right-facing dihedral that leads to a large ledge atop the pillar forming the dihedral.

content.description: The cruxes are just off the first bolt and just above the last bolt.
content.protection: Quick draws.
content.location: This climb is just left of "Monkey Do" on the arete and creates a direct start to the upper section of "Monkey Do."

content.description: This mixed route starts in the dihedral to the right of Primate Primer. Pull through a small roof to a ledge. Continue past three bolts protecting fun moves and the crux which is an committing move to gain a stance. Ten more feet get you to chain anchors. I would have placed the anchors higher to allow about 10 more feet of moderate climbing but rock quality prevented this.
content.protection: A rack of singles from .5-#3(BD) and doubles of #1 and #2. Stoppers could come in handy as well. Three sport draws for the bolts.
content.location: Located to the right of Primate Primer

content.description: Easy face past 3 bolts to fun crack with diversity of moves including chimneying.
content.protection: Three bolts protect the opening moves to crack taking mostly medium to large cams.
content.location: Upper Jungle between "Baby Gorillas are Cute" and "Curious George."

content.description: This route has its crux at the first bolt where the rock is not as good as could be.  The rest of the route is exceptional 5.9 moves on great rock.  Climb past five bolts to anchors.
content.protection: Quick draws.
content.location: Upper Jungle just left of "Climbers in the Mist" and just right of "Lucy in the Sky" of which it shares the anchor.

climbs.name: The Great Ape Escape
climbs.fa: P. Curry, R. Suggett, and R. Magner

content.description: This sport crack/face has it's crux at the start.  The thin crack opens periodically for finger jambs. At the sixth bolt with the gray hanger, you may opt to go left to a lie-backing flake where large cams are needed, or go straight up to bolt and difficult face climbing.  Both options lead to the same anchor.
content.protection: Quick draws and a couple of medium to large cams to shunts.
content.location: This route, in the "Upper Jungle," is characterized by a smooth, red band of rock at the base where a thin crack leads to two close-to-the-ground bolts.  It is just right of "Climbers in the Mist."

content.description: A fun and diverse crack on the left side of a face. Begin climbing a 10 foot hand crack to a shallow dihedral. Fun and easy to protect, this route eases off as you work your way higher. Fun movement with nice rests.
content.protection: A single rack of cams up to a #5 camalot.
content.location:
Right of

Monkey Bumps

and just left of

Rampage

. Look for a short hand crack at the start.

content.description: An excellent long crack with finger to fist-width that often requires lie-backing.
content.protection: A wide assortment of cams to chains.
content.location: This route, in the "Upper Jungle," is the obvious crack to the right of "Primate Primer."

content.description: This route begins in an easy off-width, then a reachy move right (protected by a bolt) gets you into the main finger crack that leads to shuts.
content.protection: One quick draw, and an assortment of cams, mostly small.
content.location: This route lies just right of "Climbers in the Mist."

content.description: This long and superb crack begins on "Gorillas in the Crack" for the first few moves before moving right up onto a ramp.  Moving right and up past four bolts, reach a tough but do-able crack to chains.
content.protection: A wide assortment of cams and quick draws.
content.location: This route shares the starting crack with "Gorillas in the Crack" but diverges right over a small head wall and onto a ledge.  This ledge leads right and up past four bolts to the upper section crack and chains which is the same anchor for "Monkey Bumps."

content.description: A short but sweet off-width/fist crack leads to jug hauling to the top. Traverse left to the last bolt of Ape Factor and continue up to the anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 4", one bolt (the same last bolt as Ape Factor), Chain anchors.
content.location: First obvious line in the Upper Jungle, just right of Ape Factor. Start in the obvious wide crack.

content.description:
Like the Colobus Monkey, this

black and white

crack is nicer than it looks. Not nearly as funky as it's namesake, this well protected line climbs fast and smooth. Follow the constricting break up and left to a chain anchor. Good moves and good protection.

Start directly right of

Baby Gorillas are Cute

in a large, tapering crack. Fun and surprising movement.
content.protection: Large to small cams, from a #5 camalot and down.
content.location:
Close to the entrance of the

Upper Jungle

, the

Colobus Crack

is the obvious line before the entrance of the gully.

content.description: Six bolts placed on the best quality rock avaible along this line, which creates some need for runners.  The moves are fun and end at the same anchor as "Maguilla Gorilla."
content.protection: Quick draws and runners.
content.location: Upper Jungle just left of "Maguilla Gorilla" at the very end of the arc of cliffs.

content.description: This is an especially strenuous crack that requires some off-width technique near the top.
content.protection: Medium to large cams and lots of them!  Chains at the top.
content.location: This route is to the left of "Great Ape Escape" and just to the right of "Maguilla Gorilla."

content.description: A sequency face with the crux near the last bolt.
content.protection: Quick draws to shuts.
content.location: Second "sport" route to the left of "Ape Factor" in the "Upper Jungle."

content.description: This route is a bolted face in a talus shoot.
content.protection: Quick draws to chains.
content.location: Third "sport" route to the left of "Boris Ascends Again" in the "Upper Jungle."

climbs.name: And on the Third Day he Bolted

content.description: After 2 days of projecting an overhung tips crack somewhere in the Jungle, we had to have a talk.  Our skin was fried, our muscles devastated, and our ibuprofen supplies depleted, we realized we needed an easy day.  This was our solution.  Climb the first 2 bolts of Silverback, place a cam in the bottom of the dihedral with a 4 foot runner, then cut left to a crack splitting the head wall.  Several feet cuts, and awesome heel hook, and even a sloper make for some fun moves.
content.protection: .2 or .3 for the start, 2 bolts of silverback, .5 or .75 with a long sling, then 5 new bolts to a two bolt anchor
content.location: Start on Silverback, then aim for the crack splitting the head wall to the left.

climbs.name: Ape Factor
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Rich Magner, & Phyllis Suggett

content.description: This is a pumpy, meandering crack/face sport route to chains.  The first crack moves are the crux but can be protected by clipping bolts to alternate start straight up to face climbing.
content.protection: Medium-sized cams are optional.  Quick draws and runners to chains.
content.location: This is the first "sport" route at the base of the primitive trail marked by cairns in the "Upper Jungle." (see topo on front page)
